bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, February 24, 1940

div1.p: Andrus is disappointed that Moran refuses to sign an affidavit for Lambert for the Roll of Honor. Andrus discusses his health and is happy to report that his paralysis is improving.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, February 24, 1940
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
2-24-40
FROM GUST LAMBERT
Dear Friend Lambert:
div1.p:
As is usually the case, I did not realize that so much time
had elapsed since I received your last letter. I find
that you wrote it October fifth and that you enclosed a page
from the encampment proceedings of the Spanish War Vets.,
which you asked me to return.

Am sending it back with this and am sorry that it has taken
so long to comply with your request. Our friend Kissin-
ger certainly does continue to cash in on his yellow fever
experience. Should think his professional heroism would
make him feel rather cheap when he meets any of the gang who
knows the entire story - IF he ever does.

You say, in your last letter, that you are feeling much bet-
ter and that your legs are behaving more as legs should.
I earnestly hope that the improvement will have continued so
that you are your, old self again.

Had a letter from Schwieger a few days ago but will not tell
you anything about what he had to say as you probably see
him quite often and know a lot more than I could tell you.

You will recall that, some time ago, I wrote Moran, at your
suggestion, asking if he would make a affidavit for you.
I had a reply from him - about which I wrote you. I wrote
him a second time, taking exception to some of his conclu-
sions. This must have made the lad sore as I have not
heard from him since and, before that, I had been hearing
from him quite often. It's funny that some people cannot
bear to have anyone disagree with them.

It will be eight years, the first of March, since I went to
bed. A few weeks ago I began to, slowly, lose the use of
my right hand. It progressed to a point where it was very
difficult for me to feed myself or to shave. My right
foot was also affected but this was not so annoying as loss
of use of the hand.

Then I got a new mattress and all that trouble, slowly, cleared
up so that I am almost back to normal again.

Other than that we have all been as well as usual except for
minor colds, etc.

Mrs. Andrus joins me in sending kindest regards to Mrs. Lambert
and yourself.
